sections: This is the Weekend Reading List, for paying subscribers. It starts with a short note from me, and below that are the must-reads of the week. Please use the comments section at the bottom to offer any feedback! - Sirota

If you’re paying attention to the news — or breathing in ashen air — it’s hard not to feel despondent these days, and I just want you to know: you aren’t alone. I think all of us who aren’t billionaires are feeling it right now.

I’m one of those people who may seem like a pessimist on the outside, but I do this work because I am an optimist. I’ve spent my adult life working on campaigns, doing journalism and now building this grassroots-funded media outlet because I still believe we can turn things around — but I confess that these are among the darkest days I ever remember experiencing.

When I don’t let the darkness overtake me, I am finding more motivation than ever to do this work — and I think you will appreciate our reporting this coming week on the climate crisis, the pandemic and the upcoming election.

This past week is still haunting me. It’s been a few days since we learned that Donald Trump lied to the public about a public health crisis and Bob Woodward suppressed that fact. I’m not over it. I honestly don’t think I’ll ever be over it, because the whole affair has exposed a deep rot at the core of both politics and media. To me, it is the emblematic story of our greed-is-good culture. Trump lied for his own political purposes, and a journalist aided and abetted that crime to juice book sales — and 200,000 people died. Nothing seems sacred anymore — and that’s upsetting.

on this situation elicited some angry responses in defense of Woodward, which only served to stoke the question that haunts me: does anyone really even understand what a journalist’s job is anymore? I genuinely think lots of people do not even know that journalism is not supposed to time the release of stories to elections (or book sales) and is not supposed to publish or suppress information based on a theory of how much a story will change things.

When I went to journalism school, we were taught that in making publishing decisions, you simply evaluate whether information is in the public interest — and you make that evaluation without fear or favor.

The fact that some readers think it is the journalist’s job to shill for particular candidates or aid and abet particular political outcomes — well, it suggests that so much of this country actually wants propaganda, not real journalism. And I’m sorry, any journalist aiding and abetting Trump’s dishonesty is no hero — they should be considered a pariah.

Of course, I very much appreciate all the feedback on our stories — your comments and input are so important to this project, even when we disagree. And here’s the thing: we consider and learn from everyone’s input all the time, but we will never change the fundamental thing we do.

Whether it’s reporting on the pandemic, climate change, economic policy or elections, we aim to hold power accountable, regardless of who that may offend. As the Weekend Reader below proves, if you want party propaganda, that’s not what we do here. We are one of the few outlets that isn’t shilling for a party or a corporate agenda, and frankly, I’m proud of that.

Let me also add one more thing that I know I say often, but is always worth repeating: we couldn’t do this work without the support of our supporting subscribers. So thank you so so so so much for your help in making this accountability journalism project possible. Onward.
When Obama Was Pushed To Support Single-Payer
Woodward Is Now Trump’s Human Shield To Help Him Win The Election
Bob Woodward Aided Trump's Crime Against Humanity
Health Care Lobby Tries To Buy Corporate Immunity From Both Parties
Colleges and Universities Lobby for Liability Protection As They Reopen
The Labor Day Graph That Says It All
Rebuilding the Economy Will Require Joe Biden to Think Very Differently Than 2009
The great economist Jamie Galbraith notes that our reporting forced Joe Biden’s campaign to stop promoting GOP talking points — but he argues that their “reassurance is not reassuring.”
Cuomo Is To Blame For New York’s Plight
on how New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s loyalty to his donors has harmed New Yorkers during the pandemic — now the
does a deep dive into just how much control Cuomo had over the entire situation.
Ed Markey Has a Message for Democrats: ‘The Age of Incrementalism Is Over’
on how Ed Markey was the progressive choice in the Massachusetts Senate primary, and now that he’s won his primary, Markey has a message for the Democratic Party.

“The 78 days from November 3 to January 20, known as the transition, have kept me awake at night since I started reporting out this article. The coming interregnum is likely to be one of the most politically, economically, and socially fraught periods in American history, one that could set the trajectory for the nation’s future.”
We Need to Restore an Economy for the Common Good

“The commons is not a winner-takes-all economy, but an all-take-the-winnings economy. Shared ownership encourages shared responsibility, which in turn engenders a longer-term perspective on business practices. Nothing can be externalized to some ‘other’ player, because everyone is part of the same trust, drinking from the same well.”
How Amazon Raised Prices to Profit from the Pandemic
A new report shows how Amazon used its market power to price gouge during the pandemic.
Rhode Island’s Progressive Wave Was Four Years In The Making
Progressives had a huge night in Rhode Island’s primary elections this past week.
Oregon Voters To Decide on Limitless Corporate Political Donations
Oregon has no limits on corporate or individual campaign donations — a new ballot initiative seeks to start changing that.
When Republicans and Unions Got Along
A good reminder that the GOP has not always waged a war on organized labor — that is a relatively new thing that has come with terrible consequences.
The Tarkin Doctrine and the Sith Way of War
I’m a huge Star Wars fan, and
to see it at the drive-in at the scenic Red Rocks. This article is one of my favorites — it diagnoses the political and military themes behind the original series.
I am increasingly convinced that Ferris Bueller was Cameron’s imaginary friend.
Bob Woodward Sacrificed Public Health For Book Sales
(Rising) — I appeared on Rising with Krystal Bal and Sagaar Enjeti to discuss our reporting on Bob Woodward and why he helped Donald Trump suppress crucial public health information.
